context:
patient_presentation: A 35-year-old previously healthy man was transferred to our hospital for presumed new diagnosis of penetrating Crohn's disease (CD).
additional_history: After clinical improvement, he was discharged on a corticosteroid taper and antibiotics with plans for additional small bowel evaluation.
initial_laboratory_results: Upper and lower endoscopy with ileal intubation were normal.
imaging_test_with_photo: Magnetic resonance enterography showed long-segment ileal inflammation and duodenal to transverse colon fistula with small, nondrainable abscesses (Figure A) consistent with CD.
next_imaging: Repeat magnetic resonance enterography showed a blind ending bowel loop in the right upper quadrant (Figure B) and almost complete resolution of imaging abnormalities. 
third_imaging: This suspicion was confirmed by right hemiabdomen focal uptake on Meckel scan (Figure C), and laparotomy demonstrating diverticulum with ectopic gastric mucosa.
diagnosis: This improvement favored an alternate self-limited process, such as perforated Meckel diverticulitis.

context:
patient_presentation: A 52 year old Bangladeshi man with history of ulcerative colitis was admitted to hospital with profound weight loss, generalised abdominal pain, persistent vomiting for several weeks.
additional_history: He has been immunosuppressed secondary to treatments for ulcerative colitis.
imaging_test_with_photo: Cross sectional computer tomography imaging showed marked duodenitis with obstruction causing distended fluid filled duodenum (FIGURE A, B).
next_imaging: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy demostrated gastritis with severe duodenal bulb inflammation (FIGURE C).
diagnosis: ...strongyloides stercoralis present with crypts.

context:
patient_presentation: A 52-year-old asymptomatic woman presented for a screening colonoscopy.
additional_history: Her only significant history was that she emigrated from the Republic of Burundi in East Africa 8 years prior.
imaging_test_with_photo: On colonoscopy, there was a distinct mucosal pattern with prominent distorted vasculature and scattered white punctate lesions, which was more pronounced in the right colon (Figures A and B).
diagnosis: ...characteristic of Schistosoma mansoni.

context:
patient_presentation: A 28-year-old woman presented with a 11-year history of chronic intermittent abdominal pain and difficult defecation.
additional_history: During the last 2 months, her symptoms were aggravated and they were not alleviated after a treatment with intravenous fluids and antibiotics in a local hospital. She had no significant past medical history.
initial_laboratory_results: Her laboratory studies on routine blood, serum C-reactive protein and tuberculosis specific IgG/IgM antibodies almost showed normal, but routine stool examination found some red cells and the result of fecal occult blood test was positive. 
imaging_test_with_photo: A computed tomography scan showed a thickened and edematous large intestine as well as lots of calcifications on the colon wall and in the branches of the colonic blood vessels (Figure A–C).
next_imaging: Colonoscopy showed dark purple mucosa with many ulcers and erosions in the colon and rectum (Figure D).
third_imaging: Under the barium enema examination, it showed a stiff large intestine in a sausage shape, and a loss of normal haustra of the colon (Figure E).
diagnosis: As her symptoms were not alleviated by the conservative therapy, we finally performed exploratory laparotomy for this patient.

context:
patient_presentation: A 54-year-old man was diagnosed with early gastric cancer according to an initial esophagogastroduodenoscopy finding of an IIc lesion in the gastric body (Figure A).
imaging_test_with_photo: ...an initial esophagogastroduodenoscopy finding of an IIc lesion in the gastric body (Figure A).
next_imaging: Magnifying endoscopy with narrow-band imaging identified a well-defined lesion with distorted, dilated, and partially sparse central microglandular structures. In addition, the microvessels obviously were distorted, dilated, and partially disappeared (Figure B). Endoscopic ultrasound showed that the superficial layer of the mucosa was thinned, whereas the deep layer was thickened. The deep layer was approximately 1.4-mm thick at its deepest part. The submucosa and muscularis propria were intact.
diagnosis: Amyloidosis was diagnosed....Primary gastric focal amyloidosis was diagnosed.

context:
patient_presentation: A 65-year-old man with a significant past medical history of peripheral vascular disease requiring aortofemoral bypass graft placement in 2009 owing to severe symptoms. 
additional_history: Since the surgery in 2009 there had not been any complications involving his graft. His past medical history was also significant for gastrointestinal (GI) history of celiac disease, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and esophageal strictures requiring dilation on 2 occasions. He is followed by a gastroenterologist in the outpatient clinics for these issues and has been stable for many years. His initial presentation to the emergency room was with a clinical picture suggestive of septic shock endorsing symptoms of fevers, chills, rigors, and new-onset nausea. 
physical_exam: On physical examination, vital signs showed a temperature of 39.9°C, heart rate of 110 beats/min, respiratory rate 22 breaths/min, and blood pressure of 70/48 despite receiving 4 L of normal saline. Other than signs of poor peripheral circulation and epigastric pain on palpation the physical examination was otherwise noncontributory. He was subsequently admitted to the Intensive Care Unit. 
initial_laboratory_results: His biochemistry showed a white blood cell count of 3.9 x 10^9 (reference range, 3.5–12 x 10^9), C-reactive protein of 35.4 mg/L (reference range, 0.0–8.0), and a lactate level of 3 mmol/L (reference range, 0.5–2.2). The remainder of his bloodwork, which included electrolytes, liver function tests, coagulation status, and creatinine, were all normal.
imaging_test_with_photo: However, closer review and inspection of the ulcer highlighted a circumferential abnormality within the ulcer edges that seemed to have a regular stripped pattern (Figure A).
diagnosis: During the intensive care admission, he acutely developed increasing left ankle, foot, and toe pain. Examination of the skin revealed the presence of non-tender hemorrhagic spots suggestive for septic emboli. Investigation for the source of infectious emboli was initiated. Blood culture grew Streptococcus milleri with a negative workup for infective endocarditis. A review of the patient’s prior outpatient endoscopy report done routinely for monitoring of his celiac disease revealed a well-circumscribed ulcer.

context:
patient_presentation: A 71-year-old, asymptomatic man underwent incomplete colonoscopy for screening. 
additional_history: He had a history of surgically resected retroperitoneal well-differentiated liposarcoma 10 years prior, with local recurrence as dedifferentiated liposarcoma 6 years later. 
physical_exam: Physical examination...were unremarkable.
initial_laboratory_results: ...laboratory tests were unremarkable. 
imaging_without_photo: He underwent computed tomography colonography (CTC) to evaluate the colon segments not assessed by conventional colonoscopy. 
imaging_test_with_photo: The CTC demonstrated a 3-cm pedunculated polyp in the ascending colon on the supine acquisition (Figure A, axial soft tissue window; arrow; Figure B, coronal lung window) and on 3-dimensional endoluminal view (Figure C, arrow). The polyp was homogeneous and showed soft tissue attenuation, with no fat attenuation (Figure A).

patient_presentation: An 80-year-old man was referred for severe, persistent rectal pain.
additional_history: He received brachytherapy and external beam radiation therapy 2 years ago and developed episodic hematochezia.
imaging_test_with_photo: Representative magnetic resonance images (Figures A and B) showed an anterior rectal wall (dotted line) defect, a collection (arrowhead) anterior to the rectum (arrow), and a communication between the prostate and rectum through the anterior rectal wall defect. A small prostate abscess (asterisk) was seen.
diagnosis: Colonoscopy showed moderate radiation proctitis near the dentate line.

context:
patient_presentation: A 46-year-old man with human immunodefiency virus and treatment noncompliance presented with 2 days of coffee-ground emesis and upper abdominal pain. 
additional_history: His vital signs were normal and there were no skin or oropharyngeal lesions. Abdominal examination showed mild epigastric tenderness without palpable masses and lung examination identified corase breath sounds
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory findings were notable for a hemoglobin level of 8.3 g/dL, a CD4 count of 24 per mm^3, and an albumin level of 2.1 g/dL. 
imaging_test_with_photo: An abdominal computed tomography showed a thickened, irregular stomach. A computed tomography of the chest showed innumerable small nodules distributed along bronchovascular bundles, a finding typical of pulmonary Kaposi sarcoma. Upper endoscopy showed a poorly distensible stomach (Figure A) with severely nodular, erythematous, and friable mucosa involving the gastric body (Figure B), fundus, and antrum.
diagnosis: Pulmonary Kaposi sarcoma.

context:
patient_presentation: A 58-year-old man presented with a 3-month history of weight loss and dysuria.
initial_laboratory_results: Urinalysis and blood investigations including the complete blood count, liver function test, carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen 19-9, and prostate-specific antigen were within normal limits.
imaging_without_photo: A cystoscopy was performed, which revealed findings suspicious for a colovesical fistula or bladder diverticulum.
imaging_test_with_photo: Computed tomography (CT) performed demonstrated an incidental finding in the pancreas (Figures A and B).

patient_presentation: A 59-year-old female with a history of intermittent epigastric pain for four months.
initial_laboratory_results: She was negative for Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori).
imaging_test_with_photo: ...a large 2 cm gastric ulcer (Figure A).
next_imaging: Repeat EGD showed completely healed ulcer (Figure D) but repeat biopsy still showed presence of MALT lymphoma.
diagnosis: ...consistent with a primary gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma.

context:
patient_presentation: A 61-year-old White woman with 16-year history of small bowel Crohn disease (CD) presented to the emergency department with acute right lower abdominal pain for 3 days.
additional_history: No precipitating factors were elicited on history.The patient denied usage of nonsteroidal anti-flammatory medications. A colonoscopy and a magnetic resonance enterography 18 and 7 months prior were both unremarkable. Her CD had been in clinical, radiologic, and endoscopic remision without maintenance therapy for more than 10 years except for 2 courses of budesonide. 
physical_exam: Physical examination was remarkable for right lower abdominal tenderness.
imaging_test_with_photo: A non-contrast computed tomography scan demonstrated new focal asymmetrical wall thickening in the proxmal ascending colon suspicious for malignancy (Figure A).
next_imaging: Colonoscopy revealed a 3 x 4 cm segmental area of congested, deeply ulcerated area with contact friability and decreased vascularity in the ascending colon (Figure B).
diagnosis: The patient's symptoms resolved in 2 days and she was discharged with a diagnosis of acute colonic ischemia.

context:
patient_presentation: A 44-year-old man was referred to our hospital with recurrent abdominal discomfort and chronic diarrhea resulting in repeated acute kidney injury owing to intravascular volume contraction. 
additional_history: His medical history comprises proctocolectomy with ileal pouch–anal anastomosis for ulcerative colitis and liver transplantation for primary sclerosing cholangitis 10 and 8 years ago, respectively. Six months before referral, liver retransplantation was conducted owing to chronic graft failure.
physical_exam: Physical examination was unremarkable except for moderate tenderness to palpation in the middle and lower quadrants of the abdomen.
initial_laboratory_results: Liver function tests and aminotransferase levels were within normal limits, creatinine was increased at admission (371 μmol/L; normal range, 59–104), and decreased upon continuous intravenous fluid administration (133 μmol/L). Extensive diagnostic workup including gastroscopy, pouchoscopy, and lower intestinoscopy did not reveal an explanation for the ongoing diarrhea. The stool frequency was approximately 10/d with a cumulative volume of >4 L that totally receded upon fasting.
imaging_test_with_photo: Magnetic resonance revealed marked tortuosity of the splenic vein (Figure A, *) and a filiform stenosis of the portal vein anastomosis (Figure A, arrow).

patient_presentation: A 35-year-old healthy man was admitted to our hospital with watery diarrhea for 10 days.
initial_laboratory_results: Although basic laboratory studies were normal...
imaging_test_with_photo: ...computed tomography of the abdomen revealed thickened duodenum (Figure A) and mesenteric lymphadenopathy.
next_imaging: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed innumerable 2- to 8-mm sessile pink nodular lesions carpeting the entire examined duodenum (Figure B).
diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with nodular lymphoid hyperplasia.

context:
patient_presentation: A 60-year-old man with C3 tetraplegia was referred to our department for evaluation of abdominal pain and hematochezia.
additional_history: He was diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency 5 years prior and has been taking low dose prednisolone (7.5 mg) once a day. One year before presentation, he complained of intermittent loose, mucoid stool and abdominal pain....However, the symptoms improved without any treatment, and he was discharged from the rehabilitation department. He was re-admitted for respiratory rehabilitation owing to dyspnea. On hospital day 4, he complained of abdominal pain and passing loose stool with foul odor 4 to 5 times a day. On hospital day 7, the abdominal pain worsened, and hematochezia occurred.
physical_exam: On physical examination, he was hemodynamically stable and was afebrile. The abdomen was soft with mild tenderness on palpation in the periumbilical area without peritoneal signs.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory studies were notable with a hemoglobin level of 10.7 g/dL, total protein 4.09 g/dL, and albumin 2.21 g/dL. Inflammatory marker (C-reactive protein) was mildly elevated to 1.83 mg/dL. Serology for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) was negative. Tumor markers, such as carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), carboyhydrate antigenic determinant (CA 19-9), and α-fetoprotein, were within the normal range. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody was negative, and rheumatic factor was within the normal range. Stool for acid-fast bacillus and Clostridium difficile toxin were negative; no pathogens were cultured, and no parasites were identified.
imaging_test_with_photo: Sigmoidoscopy revealed multiple small yellowish plaques in the sigmoid colon (Figure A).
next_imaging: Sigmoidoscopy revealed diverse, multiple polypoid lesions (3 mm-10 mm) with erythema, edema, and friability surrounding the entire lumen on the sigmoid colon (Figure B). The number and size of the polypoid lesions increased compared with the endoscopic findings obtained a year prior. The lesions easily bled on contact. 
third_imaging: The abdominal computed tomography scan showed multiple polyps less than 1 cm that were confined to the sigmoid colon (Figure C, arrow).

patient_presentation: A 68-year-old man with type II diabetes presented to the emergency department with acute urinary retention, which was relieved by urethral catheterization. 
additional_history: Before this episode, he had progressive urinary frequency and slow urinary stream for 3 months. He reported no abdominal pain, weight loss, bloody stool, or bowel habit change.
physical_exam: On examination, he was afebrile. His abdomen was supple and without tenderness. Digital rectal examination confirmed a firm, irregular tumor in the anterior rectal wall. 
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory test results including white blood cell count (9030/μL), hemoglobin level (14.2 g/dL) were normal, and normal results were obtained for the routine urinalysis. His serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level was 1.7 ng/mL and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level was 6.0 ng/mL. 
imaging_test_with_photo: Subsequent sigmoidoscopy showed an irregular bulging submucosal tumor with friable, erythematous overlying rectal epithelium (Figure A).
next_imaging: Whole-body computed tomography revealed a locally advanced rectal tumor (Figure B) with diffuse lymphadenopathy around the mesorectum, aorta, mediastinum, and neck.
third_imaging: Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging also revealed a low signal rectal tumor with regional lymphadenopathy on T2-weighted images (Figure C).

patient_presentation: A 36-year-old man presented to our hospital with acute epigastric pain, which had started after he had eaten a rolled pickled herring at breakfast.
physical_exam: Physical examination revealed diffuse epigastric tenderness and an elevated body temperature (38.5°C) could be detected.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory tests showed a leukocytosis and a raised level of C - reactive protein.
imaging_test_with_photo: Focused abdominal ultrasound demonstrated an irregular hypoechoic area between ventral gastric wall and left liver lobe, and a hyperechoic tubular structure at pyloric region (Figure A, white arrow).
next_imaging: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed a half toothpick which had penetrated the antral wall of the stomach (Figure B).
diagnosis: Based on the sonographic diagnosis of an unclear abdominal foreign body with suspected perforation as esophagogastroduodenoscopy was performed

context:
patient_presentation: An 18-year-old man was referred for a 2-month history of abdominal pain characterized as diffuse cramping of fluctuating intensity with postprandial exacerbation.
additional_history: Before these symptoms, his medical history was unremarkable.
physical_exam: Physical examination was significant for diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding.
imaging_test_with_photo: An esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed a diffuse nodular appearance of the gastric fundus and body (Figures A-C)...
next_imaging: ...with antral sparing (Figure D).
diagnosis: Together, these features were consistent with a diagnosis of collagenous gastritis.

context:
patient_presentation: A previously healthy 41-year-old man presented to our hospital with hematochezia and syncope for 3 days.
additional_history: Single-balloon enteroscopy was performed after an initial negative esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy....A resection of the jejunal lesion was performed.
imaging_test_with_photo: Single-balloon enteroscopy showed a 10-mm submucosal protruding lesion at the proximal jejunum (Figure A)...
next_imaging: ...with a minute mucosal defect (Figure B) suggestive of a gastrointestinal stromal tumor.
diagnosis: A jejunal Dieulafoy's lesion (DL) was diagnosed.

context:
patient_presentation: A dysmorphic six-week old girl presented with abdominal distension, microcephaly and failure to thrive.
additional_history: She passed meconium within 24 hours and had a normal rectal suction biopsy however requires enemas to aid in defecation.
physical_exam: Her features include single palmar creases, hypertelorism, triangular facies, low set ears, and a flat nasal bridge without an obvious unifying diagnosis. She had significant abdominal distension with prominent veins but no organomegaly.
initial_laboratory_results: Guthrie testing, CGH array, and ZEN2G for Mowat-Wilson disease were unremarkable.
imaging_test_with_photo: Barium follow through revealed gastro-oesophageal reflux but normal transit....Abdominal x-ray showed marked gaseous dilatation of the small and large bowel with contrast present distally; there are multiple small bowel fluid levels and narrowing in the anal region (image 1).
next_imaging: Particularly of note, there are a number of diverticula arising from the distal rectum and anorectal junction (image 2).
diagnosis: Particularly of note, there are a number of diverticula arising from the distal rectum and anorectal junction.

context:
patient_presentation: An 89-year-old Caucasian man with atrial fibrillation undergoing treatment with rivaroxaban, presented with melena requiring daily blood transfusion.
additional_history: Previous esophagogastroduodenoscopies and ileocolonoscopy only showed blood in the terminal ileum. A videocapsule enteroscopy showed dark-red blood arising from the proximal jejunum without identifiable lesions.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory parameters showed normocytic normochromic anemia (hemoglobin level, 7.5 g/dL) and normal coagulation (international normalized ratio, 1.17; activated partial thromboplastin time, 23.5 s). 
imaging_test_with_photo: Subsequently, the anterograde double-balloon enteroscopy showed multiple jejunal diverticula and active oozing bleeding arising from the diverticula at the proximal jejunum (Figures A and B), tattooed with SPOT (GI Supply, Camp Hill, PA) for surgical referral. 
next_imaging: A 25-cm segmental resection of the proximal jejunum with end-to-end anastomosis was performed, including the endoscopic tattooed site (Figure C and Video).
diagnosis: The patient underwent an exploratory laparoscopy showing multiple diverticulosis in the entire small bowel with greater expression, in number and size, at the proximal jejunum.

context:
patient_presentation: An 84-year-old man presented with a tender right groin lump of a few days' duration, which was associated with nausea.
physical_exam: Physical examination revealed discomfort on deep palpation in the right groin, with no obvious cough impulse or abdominal peritonism.
initial_laboratory_results: Blood tests and abdominal radiographs were unremarkable.
imaging_test_with_photo: Computed tomography scan demonstrated a dilated fluid-filled appendix with fat stranding, which is consistent with acute appendicites (Figures A-D).
diagnosis: Interestingly, the appendix had herniated through the deep inguinal ring, resulting in an amyand hernia (AH).

context:
patient_presentation: A 24-year-old Chinese man was admitted with complaints of hematochezia of 6 months duration, high fever, leanness, and multiple papules/pustules of 1 month’s duration.
additional_history: The patient’s past and medical histories were noncontributory. His family history was remarkable for diarrhea. 
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory tests showed the following: leukocyte count, 15,070/mm^3 with 72.8% neutrophils; hemoglobin, 7.6 g/dL; erythrocyte sedimentation rate, 53 mm/h; serum albumin, 2.17 g/dL; repeat hemocultures and stool cultures were negative for enteric pathogens; antibodies for HIV-1, herpes simplex virus, and so on, and autoantibodies were all negative; T lymphocyte typing showed CD3+CD4+ T lymphocyte count, 1030/mm^3 ; CD3+CD8+ T lymphocyte count, 1900/mm^3.
imaging_test_with_photo: Skin examination revealed several 2- to 6-cm juicy, griscent, pseudovesiculated plaques/pustules scattered over the corona capitis, neck, torso, and extremities (Figure A); the palms, soles, anus, and genitalia were spared. The lesions were mild tender and nonpruritic. Conjunctiva congestion and lips emphlysis was revealed. Oral cavity examination revealed several 2-to 4-mm ulcers, which were shallow and painful, on the gingiva, buccal mucosa, and tongue.
next_imaging: Colonoscopy revealed massive mucosal erosions, ulcers, hemorrhage, necrosis and circumscriptus pseudopolyps in the rectum, sigmoid, descending, transverse, and ascending colon (Figure B).

patient_presentation: A 65-year, old, healthy woman underwent gastroscopy and colonoscopy because of altered bowel habits and mild epigastric pain. 
additional_history: The previous medical history was unremarkable except for a complicated hysterectomy a few years ago.
imaging_test_with_photo: A computed tomography scan (Figure A) of the abdomen was done.
diagnosis: Four days after the examination, the patient presented in the emergency room with left upper quadrant pain that started approximately 12 hours after the endoscopic examination and was increasing in intensity. Blood pressure and heart rate were unremarkable, the abdomen showed no peritoneal signs but a pain on palpation in the left upper quadrant.

context:
patient_presentation: A 76-year-old man presented with recurrent urinary tract infections and nonbloody watery diarrhea.
additional_history: He had a remote history of prostate cancer that was treated with external beam radiation.
initial_laboratory_results: Stools for pathogens were negative.
imaging_test_with_photo: A colonoscopy was performed that was normal, except for what appeared to be a fistulous opening in the rectum (Figure A).
next_imaging: A computed tomography cystogram of the pelvis with contrast administered through a catheter in the bladder showed contrast in the rectum and sigmoid colon (Figure B).
diagnosis: Rectovesical fistula

context:
patient_presentation: An 85-year-old woman with a history of recurrent gastrointestinal bleeding caused by duodenal arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) presented to the hospital with recurrent melena and symptomatic anemia.
imaging_test_with_photo: An esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed fresh blood immediately upon entry of the second portion of the duodenum (Figure A).
next_imaging: Washing and irrigation showed 6 separate AVMs throughout the duodenum (Figure B). These lesions were ablated successfully with argon plasma coagulation (APC). Despite continued irrigation, fresh blood emanated from the area of the major papilla.
third_imaging: The APC probe was used to lift the major papilla for better inspection (Figure C). This maneuver showed an AVM hiding on the underside of the major papilla.
diagnosis: ...recurrent gastrointestinal bleeding caused by duodenal arteriovenous malformations (AVMs)...

context:
patient_presentation: An 82-year-old man with a 4-month history of mild anemia and elevated C-reactive protein underwent computed tomography scanning.
imaging_test_with_photo: (computed tomography scanning); revealed a large intragastric mass (Figure A).
next_imaging: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed a 7-cm pedunculated polypoid tumor with necrotic substance and hyperplastic changes in the middle body of the stomach (Figure B).
diagnosis: These findings were compatible wtih a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma. The tumor specimen had a negative margin.

context:
patient_presentation: A 54-year-old man presented with a 2-month history of an abdominal rash, initially small papules over the epigastrium that spread medially and subsequently becoming painful.
additional_history: His past medical history included decompensated hepatitis C cirrhosis with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) BCLC stage B diagnosed one year prior to presentation (3 lesions, largest measuring 5 cm). He underwent chemoembolization followed by cyberknife radiation 6 months prior to current presentation.
physical_exam: Physical examination revealed a Sister Mary Joseph's nodule surrounded by erythematous tender subcutaneous nodules (Figure a).
initial_laboratory_results: His serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) was 1000 ng/ml. 
imaging_test_with_photo: ...a Sister Mary Joseph's nodule surrounded by erythematous tender subcutaneous nodules (Figure a).
diagnosis: ...consistent with high grade adenocarcinoma of hepatobiliary origin.

context:
patient_presentation: A 24-year-old African American man with a medical history of chronic constipation for decades, morbid obesity, and tobacco dependence presented to the emergency room with acute abdominal pain and urinary retention for a day.
imaging_test_with_photo: A computed tomography scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed copious solid stool in the rectum and sigmoid colon displacing all abdominal and pelvic orangs (Figures A and B).
diagnosis: ...suggesting Hirchsprung's disease...

context:
patient_presentation: A 68-year-old female presented to the Emergency Room of our Hospital with reduced consciousness, fever (38.5°C/101.3°F) and abdominal pain. 
additional_history: The patient had been taking over the last 3 months tilidine (a synthetic opioid analgesic), ibuprofen and prednisolone because of a spinal disc herniation. The patient’s medical history revealed a chronic Leriche syndrome. 
physical_exam: The initial clinical and neurological examination showed the following findings: the patient was hemodynamically stable, in a confused state, discrete signs of meningism (positive Kernig’s sign), spontaneous movement of all extremities without localizing signs, mild increased tone of all extremities and spontaneous opening of eyes, which were equal and reactive to light. The abdomen was soft with tenderness in both lower quadrants. 
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory testing revealed a leukocytosis (16.3 /nl, ref.: 4.0-9.0), moderate increased C-reactive protein (46.6 mg/l, ref.: <5), mild increased neutrophils ratio (83.3%, ref.: 50-75), mild increased glucose (176 mg/ dl, ref.: 70-115), almost normal hemoglobulin value (11.4 g/dl) and normal electrolytes. SpO2 was 89.8 % (ref.: 95- 98.5%).
imaging_test_with_photo: A head, chest, abdomen and pelvic contrast enhanced CT scan revealed following abnormal findings (figures A-B).

patient_presentation: A 62-year-old woman who was maintained on prednisolone at 5 mg/d for autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) was evaluated for a mass in the common bile duct on ultrasonography. 
initial_laboratory_results: She had no symptoms, and laboratory findings including hepatobiliary enzymes and CA19.9 levels were normal other than an elevated serum immunoglobulin (Ig) G4 level (690 mg/dL; normal, <135).
imaging_without_photo: On F-18 fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET), uptake of FDG was detected in the lesions. On intraductal ultrasonography, the tumors seemed to be continuous with the extensively thickened bile duct wall where the lumen was not stenotic. 
imaging_test_with_photo: Computed tomography showed 2 masses (arrows) in the upper and middle bile duct and swelling of an abdominal lymph node (short arrow, Figure A), but no abnormality in the pancreas. 
next_imaging: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) showed 2 defects (Figure B, arrows) laterally in the upper and middle bile duct (Figure B).
third_imaging: Peroral cholangioscopy revealed submucosal tumor showing a smooth surface with proliferation of blood vessels (Figure C).

patient_presentation: An elderly woman was seen in the Gastroenterology Clinic to evaulate 6 months of weekly episodic, left-sided, postprandial abdominal pain with nausea.
additional_history: Episodes typically lasted 30 minutes. The pain did not occur with every meal, and improved after emesis. Between episodes she was asymptomatic.
physical_exam: Examination was unremarkable
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory results were unremarkable.
imaging_test_with_photo: She underwent small-bowel follow-through, which captured an episode of stomach herniation with organoaxial volvulus (Figure A).
next_imaging: The stomach herniated into the thorax and rotated along the cardiopyloric axis of the stomach (Figure B, dashed line). Note the reversal of the greater curvature (line A) and lesser curvature (line B).
diagnosis: ...an episode of stomach herniation with organoaxial volvulus...

context:
patient_presentation: An 84-year-old woman was referred to our hospital for an esophageal polypoid lesion.
additional_history: The patient's past cancer history included urotherial cancer at age 61, colon cancer at age 66, endometrial cancer at age 73, and skin cancer at age 78. She also had a family history that fulfilled the revised Amsterdam criteria for Lynch syndrome.
imaging_test_with_photo: Endoscopy showed a pedunculated polyp (Figure A, left) and heterotopic gastric mucosa (HGM) (Figure A, right, arrow) in the upper esophagus...
diagnosis: Esophageal cancer in Lynch syndrome

context:
patient_presentation: A 44-year-old woman presented with a 6-month history of 4 to 6 loose stools daily.
additional_history: She denied abdominal pain, weight loss, or fatigue.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory tests including stool calprotectin were normal. Her serum carotene level as 1.7 mcg/dL (normal range, 2.3-65.0 mcg/dL), fecal elastase concentration was 120 m/d (normal level, >200 mg/g), and a stool study was positive for qualitative fat. 
imaging_without_photo: Upper and lower endoscopy and biopsy specimens taken were unremarkable. An abdominal ultrasound showed multiple pancreatic cysts.\
imaging_test_with_photo: Magnetic resonance imaging showed innumerable cysts of variable sizes, occupying the pancreas and replacing the paranchyma (Figure A).
next_imaging: There was no evidence of concomitant liver (Figure B) and kidney (Figure C) polycystic disease.
diagnosis: Isolated polycystic pancreatic disease

context:
patient_presentation: A 46 year old man was referred for evaluation of a one year history of progressive constipation, bloating, and 40 lb weight loss.
additional_history: These symtpoms had previously been attributed to Crohn's colitis but improvement was not achieved after several months of adalimumab.
imaging_test_with_photo: Computed tomography enterography demonstrated prominent distal small bowel dilation with several short segment strictures, bowel wall thickening, and mucosal hyper-enhancement (Figure A, arrow).
next_imaging: Laparotomy was pursued for surgical management of the strictures. Intraoperatively, the small bowel was massively dilated up to 15 cm, notably uncharacteristic for Crohn's-associated strictures (Figure B), and full thickness small bowel biopsies were obtained.
diagnosis: Based on these clinical and histologic features, a diagnosis of degenerative leiomyopathy complicated by intestinal pseudo-obstruction was established.

context:
patient_presentation: A 43-year-old man was evaluated for left tonsil swelling.
additional_history: He had been diagnosed 1 year earlier with a left-sided colon cancer revealed by altered bowel habits. At diagnosis, the preoperative evaluation did not show distant metastasis. The patient underwent left hemicolectomy, which showed a 4-cm, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma invading the omentum (T4a). Thirty regional lymph nodes were positive for tumor extension (N2b). There was no microsatellite instability, and no KRAS mutations were found. The tumor was classified as stage IIIc disease based on the American Joint Committee on Cancer classification. The patient then received an oxaliplatin-based adjuvant chemotherapy (modified FOLFOX6) for 6 months. Three months after the end of chemotherapy, 2 pulmonary metastases were diagnosed, 1 in each lung. A positron emission tomography-computed tomography also showed suspicious mediastinal adenopathy.
