patient_presentation: A 60-year-old woman with no known medical history presented with a 2-week history of fever and right-sided abdominal pain.
physical_exam: Hepatomegaly was present on physical examination.
imaging_test_with_photo: Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen showed a large rim enhancing, hypodense right hepatic abscess measuring 13.6 x 12.3 cm (Figure A).
next_imaging: An incidental finding of an asymmetrical wall thickening at the distal rectum was also reported (Figure B).
third_imaging: Colonoscopy was performed and the rectal tumor was seen (Figure C).
diagnosis: She underwent laparoscopic drainage of the liver abscess with 300 mL of purulent fluid drained. The patient improved symptomatically and was discharged with continuation of antibiotic therapy. Microbiological and cytologic examination of the fluid did not yield any bacterial growth or atypical cells, respectively. The patient was readmitted 3 weeks later for fever. Repeat CT showed that the hepatic abscess remained largely unchanged in size. Percutaneous drainage of the abscess was performed this time. The purulent fluid grew Enterococcous faecium and coagulase-negative Streptococci and the intravenous antibiotic therapy was escalated accordingly. She was discharged well 2 weeks later. During the surveillance CT scan that was performed 6 weeks later, although the liver collection had decreased in size, it was noted that the abscess wall had increasingly thickened.

context:
patient_presentation: A 47-year-old man with history of cocaine addiction was hospitalized after cardiac arrest.
additional_history: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation associated with subsequent doses (3+6+6mg) of ephedrine was performed. Upon ICU admission, he presented with post-anoxic encephalopathy, hyperpyrexia, DIC and multi organ failure.
initial_laboratory_results: Drug screening detected benzoylecgonine (57 ng.mL-1), ephedrine (73ng.mL-1), 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDA), 3,4-methylenedioxyamphetamine (MDMA), delta-9-tetrahydrocannobinol and morphine....
imaging_without_photo: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy evaluation revealed patchy areas in the fundus which turned out to be intense inflammation and necrosis from mucosae to muscularis mucosae (probably in relation to vasoconstriction followed by ischemia).
imaging_test_with_photo: CT scan revealed gastric intramural gas extended from the fundus along the greater curvature (Figure 1-2; white arrows).
diagnosis: Based on these findings, a diagnosis of gastric cystic pneumatosis was made.

context:
patient_presentation: A 66-year-old male with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease presents with esophageal dysphagia over a period of 2 years. 
additional_history: He is currently on proton pump inhibitors and denied any history of weight loss, odynophagia or melena.
physical_exam: Physical exam was normal.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory testing was within normal limits.
imaging_test_with_photo: Upper endoscopy (EGD) showed multiple pearly papules along the entire esophagus (figure 1), which were biopsied (figure 2, 3).
diagnosis: The pathology revealed ectopic sebaceous glands in the esophagus.

context:
patient_presentation: A 39-year-old male with stage III adenocarcinoma of the pancreas presented with right upper quadrant abdominal pain.
additional_history: Five months earlier, the patient was hospitalized for acute calculous cholecystitis complicated by gallbladder perforation, requiring antimicrobials and percutaneous drain placement, with eventual clinical resolution.
physical_exam: Physical exam revealed right upper quadrant tenderness to palpation. 
initial_laboratory_results: Labs were notable for normal WBC (4.9 x 103 / μL) and normal total bilirubin (0.3 mg/dL). 
imaging_without_photo: Computed tomography (CT) showed a thickened gallbladder wall with pericholecystic stranding.
imaging_test_with_photo: Endosonography using a linear echoendoscope revealed multiple shadowing calculi within the gallbladder lumen, along with gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid (Fig. A).
next_imaging: The gallbladder was punctured through the stomach wall using a 19-gauge aspiration needle. Contrast was injected and cholecystography showed the following image (Fig. B).
diagnosis: Cholescintigraphy (HIDA) confirmed acute cholecystitis. Patient was deemed high surgical risk and was therefore offered EUS-guided gallbladder drainage, using a lumen-apposing metal stent (LAMS), for management of acute cholecystitis.

context:
patient_presentation: A 40-year-old man presented to our hospital with attacks of crampy abdominal pain, accompanied by watery diarrhea and swelling of the legs, for the previous 8 months.
additional_history: The symptoms were mostly triggered by large, fatty meals. The patient denied any relevant medical family history, traveling outside Israel, fever, rash, or arthralgia.
physical_exam: Physical examination revealed diffuse abdominal tenderness without distension and bilateral lower leg edema.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory data indicated normal complete blood count, mild hypoalbuminemia of 3.2 g/dL, hypokalemia of 2.9 mEq/L, serology for celiac disease and human immunodeficiency virus was negative; blood cholesterol and cortisol levels were in the normal range.
imaging_without_photo: Colonoscopy disclosed normal appearance of the colon and terminal ileum. Push enteroscopy using a pediatric colonoscope confirmed video capsule endoscopy findings and multiple jejunal biopsies were collected.
imaging_test_with_photo: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen showed marked bowel wall thickening (Figure A, black arrow) throughout the jejunum and proximal ileum with 2 intussusceptions (Figure A, dashed arrow).
next_imaging: Video capsule endoscopy revealed diffusely blunted and whitish villi, with mucosal edema continuous from the duodenum to the proximalileum (Figure B).

patient_presentation: An 82-year-old man with no prior medical history was referred to our hospital for a small bowel lesion detected on transabdominal ultrasonography.
initial_laboratory_results: Blood test revealed no abnormal finding. 
imaging_without_photo: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography did not show small bowel pathology.
imaging_test_with_photo: Double balloon enteroscopy revealed a subepithelial tumor with central ulceration measuring 30 mm in size, located in the ileum (Figure A and B). Although biopsies from the ulcerated and elevated areas showed no neoplastic changes, small bowel partial resection was performed.
diagnosis: The lesion was histopathologically diagnosed as leiomyoma.

context:
patient_presentation: A 55-year-old man presented at our hospital for periodic follow-up observation.
additional_history: Fourteen years previously he had undergone right eye removal for uveal melanoma.
imaging_test_with_photo: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for survey of metastasis revealed demarcated thickening of the gastric wall, which appeared as high intensity on T1-weighted images (Figure A, arrows).
next_imaging: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed the tumor that was covered by extended gastric mucosa with foveation, and cells containing dark pigment were spread over the surface (Figure B) at the gastric body.
diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed as gastric metastasis from the original uveal melanoma.

context:
patient_presentation: A 37-year-old woman underwent a computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis at a local hospital for abdominal pain with incidental finding of a "pancreatic tail mass" (figure A).
imaging_test_with_photo: ...with incidental finding of a "pancreatic tail mass" (figure A). A subsequent magnetic resonance imaging study confirmed the CT finding.
next_imaging: A tagged damaged-red blood cell (DRBC) scan showed uptake similar to the spleen (figure B), confirming presence of intrapancreatic aberrant splenic tissue.
diagnosis: The patient was referred for possible surgical resection. At our center, a review of the abdominal CT by one of our radiologists raised suspicion that the suspected pancreatic mass may represent an accessory spleen (splenule). A tagged damaged-red blood cell (DRBC) scan showed uptake similar to the spleen (figure B), confirming presence of intrapancreatic aberrant splenic tissue.

context:
patient_presentation: A 62-year-old man with a chronic hepatitis C and liver cirrhosis Child A was referred for abdominal computed tomography (CT) after a nodular liver lesion in segment V was found on ultrasonography. 
additional_history: His medical history included esophageal varices grade I, reflux esophagitis grade III, and a posttraumatic splenectomy 50 years ago.
physical_exam: The physical examination was unremarkable...
initial_laboratory_results: ...and the laboratory values were normal (alpha-fetoprotein, 1.9μg/L). 
imaging_without_photo: Abdominal CT revealed a homogenous, smoothly outlined, round lesion measuring 15 x 18 mm located between the gallbladder and the liver (segment V).
imaging_test_with_photo: During the arterial phase the lesion seemed to be enhanced (Figure A) and during the venous phase the lesion's density was similar to the surrounding liver parenchyma (Figure B). 
next_imaging: To rule out small hepatocellular carcinoma, diagnostic laparoscopy was performed. The nodule could be visualized at the Calot's triangle of the gallbladder (Figure C).
third_imaging: We found unexpected, multiple nodules of different sizes throughout the entire left upper abdominal quadrant. These nodules were located within the greater omentum and the mesentery as well as the peritoneal surface including the left-sided diaphragm (Figure D).
diagnosis: The postoperative course was uneventful.

context:
patient_presentation: A 27-year-old woman of Asian descent was referred to our department for resection of an incidentally diagnosed cystic pancreatic head tumor. 
additional_history: The patient reported episodic back and epigastric pain as well as fatigue for 2 months, which led to the diagnostic workup. There was no history of pancreatitis, jaundice, vomiting, weight loss, fever, or night sweats....She had last visited her home country, Thailand, >1 year ago.
physical_exam: Physical examination...were unremarkable.
initial_laboratory_results: ...laboratory tests were unremarkable.
imaging_test_with_photo: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI; Figure A) showed a mass of the pancreatic head (encircled) with solid (blunt arrow) and cystic (arrow) areas. The mass was irregularly enhanced in the solid portion and the cystic wall when gadolinium was used. Heterogeneous iso- and hypointensity associated with high signal intensity corresponding to hemorrhage were observed. The portal vein was severely compressed and possibly infiltrated by the tumor (short arrow).
next_imaging: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP; Figure B) disclosed a discrete compression and extrahepatic dilatation (long arrow) of the distal bile duct. The pancreatic duct did not show signs of obstruction (short arrow). There was evidence of enlarged peripancreatic and hepatic hilar lymph nodes on MRI and endosonography.
diagnosis: Chest x-ray was normal.

context:
patient_presentation: A 41-year-old female with Gilbert's syndrome had elevated alkaline phosphatase levels for 3 years ranging from 170 to 195 U/L, but was asymptomatic.
additional_history: She had taken oral contraceptives for years but stopped one year prior, and denied taking medications or supplements, alcohol or drug use, or family history of liver disease. Her abdomen was soft without tenderness.
initial_laboratory_results: Additional workup demonstrated normal ALT, AST, and lipase; a mildly elevated ACE level of 83 U/L (normal 9-67), an elevated GGT of 95 U/L (normal <57), and a mildly elevated CRP of 8.5 mg/L. Viral hepatitis serologies, autoimmune serelogies, anti-mitochondrial antibody, and tumor markers including AFP and CA 19-9 were all negative.
imaging_test_with_photo: MRI showed hepatomegaly without fatty infiltration, two arterially enhancing lesions, and one with minimal enhancement (Figure A). There were also numerous isointense hypoenhancing lesions in the right lobe, the largest measuring 6.3 cm (Figures A, B, & C).
diagnosis: ...consistent with inflammatory hepatic adenomatosis (HA), defined as 10 or more hepatic adenomas.

context:
patient_presentation: A 66-year-old man with a history of gastroespohageal reflux disease presented to the clinic with halitosis for the past year unrelated to food intake.
additional_history: His recent dental examination was normal.
physical_exam: His physical exmaination was unremarkable.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory data including Helicobacter pylori antigen was unremarkable.
imaging_test_with_photo: CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 1.2 x 0.8 x 0.7 cm well-defined hyperattenuating structure in the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb (Figure A).
next_imaging: He underwent esophagogastroduodenoscopy which demonstrated a 15 mm nodule in the duodenal bulb (Figure B).
third_imaging: On endoscopic ultrasound, the lesion appeared to be located within the deep mucosa and submucoa without invasion of adjacent structures (Figure C).
diagnosis: An octreotide localization study was negative for octreotide avid lesions. No etiology for patient's halitosis was found on endoscopic examination.

context:
patient_presentation: The patient was a 63-year-old man who presented with several weeks of abdominal pain and a recent diagnosis of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.
initial_laboratory_results: His CD4 count was 7 cells/μL. An abdominal ultrasound revealed a 2.9 x 3.3 cm lobulated mass at the pancreatic head. Abdominal computed tomography confirmed this finding, along with regional retroperitoneal lymphadenoptahy and a dilated biliary tree.
imaging_test_with_photo: Endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration of the pancreatic head lesion (Figure A)
diagnosis: Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare granulomatous pancreatitist in HIV-infected patient

context:
patient_presentation: A 47-year-old man with a medical history of human immunodeficiency virus infection, primary syphilis, hepatitis A, typhoid fever, and tubercular polyneuritis presented with rectorrhagia and anal flowing.
additional_history: The patient was homosexual and reported unprotected anal intercourse 3 weeks before. The human immunodeficiency virus infection was controlled by antiretroviral therapy (elvitegravir, emtricitabine, tenofovir alafenamide, cobicistat), with an undetectable viral load and a normal CD4 T-cell count....A rectal swab and biopsy samples were collected for virologic, bacteriologic, and histologic examinations. Because of the strong suspicion of sexually transmitted disease, a probabilistic treatment by doxycycline (100 mg, twice a day, for 7 days) and ceftriaxone (a 500-mg intranmuscular single dose) was prescribed. Histology examination showed nonspecific ulcerative colitis, without granuloma. Polymerase chain reaction, performed on the rectal swab, showed a Chlamydia trachomatis infection (genotype L).
physical_exam: The physical examination showed an anal purulent excretion, no inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a painful digital rectal examination, without any palpable mass.
imaging_test_with_photo: A rectosigmoidoscopy showed multiple round, slightly elevated, ulcerated lesions on the first 10 cm of the rectum (Figures A and B). Above the middle rectum, the mucosa was normal.
next_imaging: One month later, the patient did not have any symptoms and the rectosigmoidoscopy showed a complete healing of ulcers (Figure C).
diagnosis: The diagnosis of lymphogranuloma venereum proctitis was retained and doxycycline treatment was extended for a total of 21 days.

context:
patient_presentation: A 74-year-old white man with a history of decompensated alcoholic liver disease was referred to our clinic for further management of his cirrhosis. 
additional_history: The patient initially presented to an outside hospital 2 months prior with increasing abdominal girth and confusion. Small, nonbleeding esophageal varices were visualized on upper endoscopy. Doppler ultrasonography revealed a portal vein thrombus with cavernous transformation. The patient was initiated on warfarin. He presented to us for a second opinion.
physical_exam: Physical examination revealed an elderly, ill-appearing gentleman with anicteric sclera, shifting dullness and bilateral lower extremity edema.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory testing was notable for a total bilirubin of 0.8 mg/dL, alanine and aspartate aminotransferases 190 and 150 U/L, respectively, and alkaline phosphatase 1000 U/D. International Normalized Ratio was prolonged (on warfarin) at 4.2; creatinine was 1.1 mg/dL and albumin 3.2 g/dL.
imaging_test_with_photo: Triphasic computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrated a large peripancreatic lesion enhancing on portal venous phase with resultant mass effect on adjacent structures (Figure A).

patient_presentation: A 44 year old, otherwise healthy woman presented with two months of worsening abdominal pain, nausea, diarrhea, and weight loss.
imaging_test_with_photo: A CT scan showed bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy and multiple enlarged cardiophrenic lymph nodes (a). Given concern that her image findings and gastrointestinal symptoms may be related to an underlying lymphoma, she underwent an endoscopic evaluation. An upper endoscopy did not reveal any pathology.
next_imaging: However, the colonoscopy demonstrated multiple soft, semi-sessile polypoid lesions throughout the colon (b)...
diagnosis: These findings were consistent with Mantle Cell Lymphoma (MCL) involving the colonic mucosa.

context:
patient_presentation: A 56-year-old obese man was referred for the incidental finding of hepatic steatosis.
additional_history: He has diabetes and dyslipidemia and does not drink alcohol. His body mass index is 32. He has no stigmata of chronic liver disease on examination.
initial_laboratory_results: His laboratory results show an aspartate aminotransferase level of 92 U/L, an alanine aminotransferase level of 82 U/L, an albumin level of 4.2 g/dL, and a platelet count of 180 k/uL. Werologic work-up for causes of chronic liver disease was unremarkable.
imaging_without_photo: An ultrasound showed no changes other than hepatic steatosis
diagnosis: You diagnose him with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

context:
patient_presentation: An 84-year-old Caucasian man came in for follow-up endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).
additional_history: He had been diagnosed with choledocholithiasis 6 months ago, which was treated with an ERCP and placement of a 10F x 7-cm plastic stent in the common bile duct. It was followed by a laparoscopic cholecystectomy a month later. An ERCP was performed after the cholecystectomy for stent removal, which showed stricture in the common hepatic duct (CHD). A repeat 10F x 7-cm plastic stent was placed during the procedure and brushings for cytology were negative. The patient presented 3 months later for follow-up ERCP to evaluate the indeterminate stricture.
imaging_test_with_photo: During the procedure, the cholangiogram again showed a focal, severe narrowing in the CHD (Figure A) after removal of the stent.
next_imaging: A SpyGlass (Boston Scientific, Marlborough, MA) cholangioscopy was performed, which showed a surgical clip eroding into the CHD (Figure B) as the cause for narrowing, with some stone debris proximal to the clip. Subsequently, a 10 x 80 mm fully covered, self-expanding metal stent was placed with excellent flow of bile and contrast.
diagnosis: This bile injury resulted from an eroding clip diagnosed by direct cholangioscopy.

context:
patient_presentation: A 65-year-old woman with a history of end-stage renal disease presented to the hospital with odynophagia and dysphagia 4 weeks after a kidney transplant.
additional_history: At the time of admission, the patient was taking mycophenolate mofetil and tacrolimus for immunosuppression....The etiology of esophagitis was presumed to be secondary to reflux, and the patient was started on oral pantoprazole 40 mg twice daily.
imaging_test_with_photo: On initial endoscopy, the patient was found to have a 20cm hiatal hernia and severe LA D esophagitis characterized by circumferentially ulcerated mucosa from 25 to 35 cm at the gastroesophageal junction (Figure A).
next_imaging: On 2 subsequent upper endoscopies in the following 3 months, the patient was found to have persistent severe esophagitis with minimal improvement despite endorsing compliance and trials of various proton pump inhibitor therapies (Figure B).
third_imaging: On follow-up endoscopy, there was complete healing and resolution of the esophagitis and symptoms (Figure C).
diagnosis: Given concern for immunosuppressant-related esophagitis, mycophenolate mofetil was discontinued. (Mycophenolate mofetil-induced esophagitis).

context:
patient_presentation: A 47-year-old man with a history of decompensated liver cirrhosis was admitted to our hospital owing to the passage of tarry stools for 3 days. 
additional_history: Two days later, the patient developed progressive abdominal pain accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and cold sweating. 
physical_exam: At that time, physical examination revealed tenderness in the epigastric area without muscle rigidity or rebound pain.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory studies revealed anemia (hemoglobin, 9.9 mg/dL), thrombocytopenia (platelets, 34,000/μL), elevated serum bilirubin (9.1 mg/dL), low serum albumin (2.1 g/dL), elevated serum lipase (809 U/L), and prolonged prothrombin time (International Normalized Ratio, 1.68).
imaging_test_with_photo: The esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) showed a duodenal ulcer with a visible, nonbleeding vessel (Figure A)
next_imaging: Endoscopic hemostasis was achieved by clipping the vessel and injection of epinephrine (12 mL, 0.2%; Figure B).
third_imaging: Noncontrast computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen at the level of second part of duodenum revealed a hyperdense lesion over the duodenum with fat stranding (Figure C).

patient_presentation: An 18-year-old woman presented with intermitten hematochezia.
additional_history: She had no previous history or family history of cancer.
imaging_test_with_photo: A colonoscopy showed a reddish 5-mm polyp in the sigmoid colon (Figure A).
next_imaging: Narrow-band imaging showed a brownish area on the head of the polyp (Figure B), suggestive of NICE type 2.
third_imaging: However, the surface and vessel pattern were indicative of NICE type 1 (Figure C).
diagnosis: Therefore, we suspected a hyperplastic polyp. However, because of the overlapping features of NICE type 1 and type 2, the optical diagnosis of the polyp would be low-confident. Furthermore, because this polyp was thought to be the cause of hematochezia, it was removed by endoscopic mucosal resection....The lesion was diagnosed as a carcinoma in an adenomatous polyp.

context:
patient_presentation: A 45-year-old man presented with a 4-week history of tenesmus and rectal bleeding. 
imaging_without_photo: Digital rectal examination identified a rectal mass. Ileocolonoscopy confirmed an ulcerated lesion in the distal rectum extending 7 cm from the anal verge; the rest of the colon and distal ileum presented a normal appearance. Pelvic MRI showed a thickened rectal wall, without lymphadenopathies or any other abnormal findings.
imaging_test_with_photo: A sigmoidoscopy was performed (Figure B, C).
diagnosis: Topical mesalazine was started. After 4 weeks the patient referred mild improvement, with persisting tenesmus and infrequent bleeding.

context:
patient_presentation: A 38-year-old woman, a known epileptic since 15 years, admitted with complaints of intermittent, low-grade fever since 3 months.
additional_history: She had persistent dry cough, fatigue, early satiety, loss of appetite, and weight loss of 6 kg over 3 months. She was on phenytoin sodium 300 mg/d and sodium valproate 1000 mg/d for epilepsy. 
physical_exam: Systematic examination was unremarkable.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory evaluation revealed the following abnormalities: hemoglobin, 10.6 g/dL; erythrocyte sedimentation rate, 114 mm/hr; serum albumin, 3 g/dL; and serum globulin, 4.8 g/dL. 
imaging_without_photo: Renal function tests, serum bilirubin, and liver enzymes were normal. Chest roentgenogram was within normal limits. Computed tomography (CT) of the brain done 2 years earlier and magnetic resonance imaging of the brain in the past year for a history of seizures showed a left frontal lobe calcified granuloma.
imaging_test_with_photo: An ultrasonography of the abdomen (Figure A, B) showed a well-defined, rounded, isoechoic lesion in the right lobe of liver with a linear tubular coiled structure within.
next_imaging: CT (Figure C) and MRI (Figure D, E) confirmed a hydatid cyst with possible rupture.

patient_presentation: A 49-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis presented with upper gastrointestinal bleeding and ascites.
additional_history: Over the following months, the patient had frequent hospitalizations for recurrent bleeding from the polyps and refractory ascites....The patient received a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt, which lowered the portosystemic venous gradient from 18 to 10 mm Hg. The patient was placed on the liver transplant list but continued to have intermittent gastrointestinal bleeding, receiving a total of 78 units of packed red blood cells within 1 year. He also required weekly parancentesis with a cumulative removal of >660 L of ascites, despite confirmation of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt patency. After liver transplantation, his ascites and gastrointestinal bleeding completely resolved.
imaging_test_with_photo: Endoscopy showed grade 2 espophageal varices with innumerable sessile polyps of the stomach and duodenum with diffuse hemorrhage (Figures A and B), which were treated wtih epinephrine injection and hemostatic clips.
next_imaging: A repeat endoscopic 1 year after transplant showed near-complete involution of the gastric and duodenal polyps (Figure D).
diagnosis: Portal hypertensive polyposis of the gastrointestinal tract

context:
patient_presentation: A 51-year-old woman with psoriatic arthritis on adalimumab presented with 2 months of diarrhea with 3 to 7 loose stools per day but no other symptoms.
physical_exam: Her abdominal examination was benign and her complete blood count was normal.
initial_laboratory_results: Stool culture, ova and parasites, Clostridium difficile polymerase chain reaction, and fecal leukocytes were negative.
imaging_test_with_photo: A colonoscopy showed pseudomembranes scattered throughout the colon (Figure A) and a normal terminal ileum.
diagnosis: ...consistent with pseudomembranous collagenous colitis (PCC).

context:
patient_presentation: A 61-year-old man with alcoholic liver cirrhosis presented to hospital with painless jaundice.
additional_history: He was previously diagnosed with primary sclerosing cholangitis by an initial magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) showing a nodular, cirrhotic liver with “beaded” intrahepatic ducts.
imaging_test_with_photo: On the current admission, a repeat MRCP showed cystic structures along the intrahepatic bile ducts (Figure A).
next_imaging: Therefore, high-resolution imaging (MRCP) is required and diagnosis is made on the findings of cystic structures independent of the biliary tree and on both sides of the portal veins, creating a “string of pearls” or “grapes on a stem” appearance (Figure B).
diagnosis: These findings were consistent with peribiliary cysts and not primary sclerosing cholangitis.

context:
patient_presentation: A 44-year-old woman with Child-Pugh A cirrhosis presented with large-volume ascites. 
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory indices showed an international normalized ratio of 1.7, a bilirubin level of 90 umol/L, WCC of 8.4 x 10^9/L, and an albumin level of 29 g/dL. Ascitic fluid analysis showed a WCC of 35 cells/mm^3, culture and cytology were negative, and the serum albumin-ascites gradient was 9 g/dL. 
imaging_test_with_photo: Cross-sectional imaging showed no hepatocellular carcinoma or pathologic lymphadenopathy. A computed tomography-positron-emission tomography scan (Figure A) showed intense uptake of a thickened peritoneum consistent with a metabolically active process.
diagnosis: ...that was tuberculosis (TB) polymerase chain reaction (PCR) positive and a fully sensitive Mycobacterium tuberculosis was cultured.

context:
patient_presentation: A 30-year-old woman presented with abdominal pain and distension for 1 month.
additional_history: There were several episodes of vomiting over the last 2 weeks. There was history of open cholecystectomy for gallstone disease 3 years back. There was no other significant past medical or family history.
physical_exam: On examination, there was no pallor or icterus. Abdominal examination revealed abdominal distension with mild tenderness in the epigastrium. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.
initial_laboratory_results: Routine biochemical and hematologic investigations were unremarkable. A diagnosis of subacute intestinal obstruction was considered. 
imaging_test_with_photo: Abdominal radiograph in erect position showed dilatation of small bowel with multiple air–fluid levels (Figure A, arrows). Ultrasonography confirmed the dilatation of small bowel loops. There was no ascites.
next_imaging: Noncontrast axial CT of the abdomen revealed dilatation of small bowel with air–fluid levels (Figure B, short arrow) and a hyperdense intraluminal lesion showed mottled air (Figure B, arrow).
third_imaging: Contrast-enhanced coronal reformatted image localised the intraluminal abnormality within the ileum (Figure C, arrow). The involved segment of bowel showed mild mural thickening and adjacent mesenteric fat stranding. The proximal small bowel was dilated (Figure C, short arrow).

patient_presentation: A 49-year-old woman presented 5 months after passage of bloody stools. 
additional_history: Five weeks prior to presentation, she experienced central infra-umbilical pain in the postprandial period and, two weeks later, an episode of severe abdominal pain diagnosed elsewhere as small bowel obstruction, which resolved without any surgical intervention. However, she continued to experience recurrent postprandial abdominal pain. There were no other symptoms. On examination, there were no abnormalities or signs of intestinal obstruction. 
imaging_without_photo: Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, colonoscopy and ileal and colonic biopsies for Crohn's disease were all negative. Capsule endoscopy revealed two small intestinal ulcers attributed to intake of NSAIDs for shoulder pain. 
imaging_test_with_photo: CT enterography showed a 15 cm long dilated segment (content air [left] or fluid [right]), diagnosed as localized ileal dilatation (wide arrow) close to the Meckel's diverticulum (narrow arrow).
diagnosis: ...diagnosed as localized ileal dilatation close to the Meckel's diverticulum....Macroscopically, there was a bulbous portion of small bowel and a 5.5 cm long Meckel's diverticulum. The adjacent small bowel showed a 0.5 cm ulcer, possibly the source of the bleeding.

context:
patient_presentation: A 58-year-old white man with refractory stage IIIA immunoglobulin G kappa multiple myeloma (MM) developed severe nausea, vomiting, and coffee-ground emesis during an extended hospitalization after salvage stem cell transplantation (SCT).
additional_history: The patient was initially diagnosed with MM 5 years before presentation, and had been treated with multiple antineoplastic therapies, including bortezomib/dexamethasone, lenalidomide, cyclophosphamide, pomalidomide, daratumumab, carfilzomib, and a failed autologous SCT. He subsequently underwent salvage autologous SCT with high-dose melphalan conditioning. The patient’s posttransplant course was notable for grade 4 mucositis with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Infectious workup for his persistent symptoms, including testing for Clostridium difficile, fecal leukocytes, Cyclospora, Giardia, Isospora, Cryptosporidium, Microsporidia, stool cultures, and ova and parasites was negative. CT of the abdomen with oral contrast was unremarkable. Supplemental enteric feeding via Dobhoff tube was initiated and symptom control was achieved with scheduled loperamide. He was discharged after adequate engraftment off immunosuppression 30 days after SCT on valacyclovir, pentamidine, micafungin, and posaconazole for prophylaxis.
physical_exam: The patient was readmitted 1 day after discharge with severe nausea, vomiting, and coffee-ground emesis. His examination demonstrated once again severe mucositis of the oropharyngeal cavity.
initial_laboratory_results: His laboratory results were significant for a hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL and a platelet count of 13,000/μL, which were not markedly different from recent baseline values.
imaging_test_with_photo: An esophagogastroduodenoscopy was performed, which revealed 3 large, cratered esophageal ulcers with adherent exudates in the upper and middle third of the esophagus without stigmata of bleeding (Figures A, B).

patient_presentation: A 15-year-old boy with a history of Crohn’s disease (CD) was admitted to the hospital because of generalized skin eruption.
additional_history: He had been healthy until 10 years ago, he experienced abdominal cramping, pain, bloody bowel movements, and weight loss of 8 kg over 6 months duration. The diagnosis of CD was made based on the findings of colonoscopy and endoscopic biopsy. Weeks after the onset of gastrointestinal (GI) tract symptoms, rashes developed on the face, upper chest, and limbs. After systemic corticosteroids, his diarrhea and cutaneous manifestation resolved gradually. One month before this admission, the patient experienced a gradual onset of diarrhea despite medical therapy.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory examination showed normal hemogram, liver, renal, thyroid functions, and serum zinc level. Stool studies revealed no evidence of infection.
imaging_without_photo: Subsequent colonoscopy showed a normal appearance of the entire colonic mucosa and terminal ileum.
imaging_test_with_photo: Two weeks later, diffuse skin eruption with multiple well-demarcated, erythematous, crusted serpiginous patches were noted symmetrically in a photodistributed manner on the neck (Figure A), axillae, hands, and feet (Figure B).
diagnosis: In addition, he experienced a gradual onset of insomnia, dizziness, and fatigue, which soon progressed to parkinsonism.

context:
patient_presentation: A 35-year-old Caucasian man presented with rectal bleeding and abdominal pain.
additional_history: His hospital course included intravenous ciprofloxacin and metronidazole. He was discharged after resolution of hematochezia and improvement of abdominal pain.
initial_laboratory_results: His hemoglobin level was 9.8 g/dL (normal range, 13.0-16.0 g/dL).
imaging_test_with_photo: Physical examination showed tendneress to a palpation in the right lower quadrant, voluntary guarding, positive Rovsing sign, and hemangiomas on the right lateral hip (Figure A).
next_imaging: A computed tomography scan showed cecal diverticulitis with concern for microperforation, altered venous drainage of the portal system, venous nodularity and calcification, and phleboliths within the wall of the rectosigmoid colon consistent with hemangiomas (Figure B).
third_imaging: Six weeks after hospital discharge, a colonoscopy identified multiple varices in the descending colon 10 to 25 mm in size, and multiple intraluminal protruding colonic varices (Figures C and D).
diagnosis: These findings are consistent with Klippel-Trénaunay-Weber syndrome, which is characterized by hemihypertrophy of soft tissue, varicose veins, and hemangiomas.

context:
patient_presentation: An 86-year-old male patient was referred to the Department of Gastroenterology at the Inselspital Bern, following a one-month history of reduced general condition, weakness, and relapsing fever. 
additional_history: During admission, he also experienced epigastric pain with tenderness on palpation. No other symptoms were noted, including weight loss, gastrointestinal bleeding, or allergies. His medical history included rheumatic disease (with long-term steroid use), mild reflux esophagitis and a hiatus hernia, colonic pandiverticulosis, valvular and hypertensive cardiopathy, and chronic renal insufficiency....Following treatment with antibiotics, his fever, inflammatory markers, thrombocytopenia, and anemia all improved.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory findings indicated elevated inflammatory markers and transaminases, thrombocytopenia, and anemia. Blood and urine cultures were sterile. 
imaging_test_with_photo: Endoscopic evaluation of the upper gastrointestinal tract revealed white mucosal plaque-like lesions in the esophagus (Figure A), a small hernia in the gastric cardia, and a normal esophageal z line.

patient_presentation: A previously healthy 20--year-old Caucasian man presented with a 6-month history of weight loss, anorexia, lethargy, and pruritus.
physical_exam: Examination revealed conjunctival pallor and hepatomegaly.
initial_laboratory_results: A full blood count demonstrated iron-deficiency anemia (hemoglobin, 7.8 g/dL; mean corpuscular volume, 63 fL; ferritin, 19 μg/L) and eosinophilia (3.32 x 10^9/L). Liver function tests showed cholestatic jaundice (bilirubin, 54 μmol/L; alkaline phosphatase, 416 U/L; alanine aminotransferase, 170 μ/L). Noninvasive liver screen, autoantibodies, immunoglobulin (Ig)G4, parasitic cytology, and stool cultures were negative.
imaging_without_photo: Liver ultrasonography demonstrated mild irregular intrahepatic duct dilatation....Gastroscopy with push enteroscopy revealed erythematous gastric body mucosa with thickened rugal folds, but normal duodenum and proximal jejunum....Colonoscopy excluded inflammatory bowel disease.
imaging_test_with_photo: Computed tomography suggested cholangiopathy with beading of the biliary tree, splenic varices, gastric mural thickening (Figure A), and multiple small bowel polyps. 
next_imaging: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography confirmed intra- and extrahepatic cholangiopathy (Figure B).

patient_presentation: A 56-year-old man with severe colic periumbilical pain and constipation for eighteen months was referred to our hospital.
additional_history: He complained of unbearable pain that came on and off every 2–3 months. He did not have fever or hematochezia. Four weeks before he came to our hospital, he went to another local hospital, where gastroscopy and colonoscopy were performed and nothing abnormal was observed. However, the patient also had abdominal CTA and right ileocolic artery stenosis was highly suspected. Then, the patient received treatment for ischemic bowel disease and no improvement in his symptoms was reported.
physical_exam: On admission to our hospital, the patient’s vital signs were normal. He had brown stains on his teeth. The chest examinations were normal. The abdominal examination revealed hypoactive bowel sounds and mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory investigation showed Hepatitis B infection (DNA level 5•78 x 10^5 copy/mL, and liver function within normal range), and mild anemia (hemoglobin concentration 103 g/L). The tests for serum iron, folate and Vitamin B12 levels all showed negative results. The urine and stool tests yielded normal results. Tests for autoimmune diseases showed negative results.
imaging_test_with_photo: Gastroscopy, colonoscopy and abdominal CTA (Figure A) were repeated and yet again produced normal results.
next_imaging: Magnetic resonance enterography showed parts of the small bowel walls thickening in the left upper abdomen (Figure B).
third_imaging: Double-balloon endoscopy revealed patchy redness and congestion at two sites between 50 cm (Figure C) and 150 cm (Figure D) from the pylorus.
diagnosis: Some time after the patient was admitted, his symptoms deteriorated so much so that he attempted suicide.

context:
patient_presentation: A 23-year-old woman presented to the clinic with complaints of heartburn and dysphagia with solid foods.
additional_history: Her family history was remarkable for gastric and lung cancer in first-degree relatives.
physical_exam: Physical exam was normal.
initial_laboratory_results: Routine laboratory study results were normal.
imaging_test_with_photo: An upper endoscopy was performed and showed multiple polypoid lesions ranging in size from 3 to 11 mm, involving the entire esophagus (Figure A; Video). An endoscopic polypectomy of several of the larger polyps was performed.
diagnosis: ...squamous papillomas with areas of hyperkeratinization.

context:
patient_presentation: A 22-year-old man ingested 2 tablespoons of elemental mercury from a home chemistry set in a suicide attempt.
additional_history: On presentation, he denied any symptoms. 
initial_laboratory_results: Vital signs and routine laboratory tests were unremarkable. His 24-hour urine mercury test result was 44 ug/L. 
imaging_test_with_photo: An acute abdominal series showed scattered radiopaque material throughout the small bowel, large bowel, and right lower lung (Figure A).
diagnosis: Scattered radiopaque material throughout the small bowel, large bowel, and right lower lung.

context:
patient_presentation: A 38-year-old man was referred to us with loss of consciousness and seizure.
additional_history: In the history taken, it was revealed that he had had tremor, low back pain, trismus, and hand/foot locking for 4 days before presentation and constipation for almost 2 months. The Glasgow coma scale was 5....No history of epilepsy was given; however, upon further questioning, the relatives gave a 10-year history of addiction to oral opium.
physical_exam: The abdominal examination was normal.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory tests were within normal limits except for a calcium level of 6.1 mg/dL and hemoglobin of 6.5 g/dL with hypochromic and microcytic red blood cells in peripheral blood smear. The patient was put on conservative treatment for hypocalcemia and seizure.
imaging_without_photo: Brain computed tomography (CT) without contrast, electroencephalogram, and lumbar puncture were ordered. Brain CT and lumbar puncture were normal; the electroencephalogram showed polyspike and wave discharges compatible with generalized seizures.
imaging_test_with_photo: An abdominopelvic CT without contrast was requested, which showed scattered radiopaque densities (Figure A).
diagnosis: The patient’s blood pressure, pulse rate, respiratory rate, and temperature were 170/110 mm Hg, 85 bpm, 40/min, and 37.2C, mandating intubation for respiratory distress. About 2 hours after presentation, he experienced another seizure episode. A neurology consult was performed; pupils were midsized and reactive to light and neck stiffness was present.

context:
patient_presentation: A 29-year-old woman was admitted to our hospital with jaundice for 1 month.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory findings showed an increased total bilirubin level (4.4 mg/dL) and direct bilirubin level (3.9 mg/dL)....The amylase level in the collected bile during ERCP was 1580 U/L, which is higher than the upper limit of serum amylase of 110 U/L.
imaging_test_with_photo: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography showed dilated intrahepatics and cystic dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct (Figure A).
next_imaging: Subsequent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) via the major papilla confirmed a markedly dilated intrahepatic biliary tree with saccular dilation of the common bile duct (Figure B). Also noted was a long common channel (20 mm) with filling of a short Duct of Wirsung branching off into fine regular arborization.
third_imaging: After placement of a double-pigtail stent in the bile duct, ERCP via the minor papilla showed a dominant dorsal duct with a normal Duct of Santorini and complete pancreas divisum (Figure C).
diagnosis: The diagnosis of a type IA choledochal cyst was made, along wtih an anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction and complete pancreas divisum.

context:
patient_presentation: A 30-year-old female presented with abdominal pain, distension, and weight loss.
additional_history: She had no significant past medical or surgical history....Extensive infectious work up, including quantiferon gold, histoplasma, legionella, and coccidiosis serologies were negative. Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt was placed which resolved her ascites.
physical_exam: Physical exam revealed a large epigastric mass.
imaging_test_with_photo: Quadruple phase abdominal magnetic resonance imaging showed numerous hypodense lesions in the left and right liver lobes with a targetoid appearance, hepatic capsular retraction and severe hypertrophy of the left lobe. The largest lesion measure 12.2 cm in the left lobe (a). There was also evidence of splenomegaly and ascites.
next_imaging: Computed tomography of the chest showed multiple scattered hypodense lesions in the bilateral lungs (b).
diagnosis: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma

context:
patient_presentation: A 40-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with intermittent abdominal pain for a week, severe constipation, and bilious vomiting for 48 hours.
additional_history: The patient reported longstanding constipation aggravated during menstruation. Apart from a normal pregnancy, she had otherwise unremarkable medical history.
physical_exam: On clinical examination, there were scarce bowel sounds and the abdomen was diffusely tender most notably in the left lower quadrant. There were no palpable masses and no feces in the rectum. Clinically, there was voluntary guarding, but no signs of peritonitis. 
initial_laboratory_results: Blood tests were within normal limits.
imaging_without_photo: Abdominal radiographs showed a distended large bowel with a remarkable distention of the left colon without small bowel involvement.
imaging_test_with_photo: Computed tomography (CT) confirmed an acute large bowel obstruction (Figure A) with a thickened rectosigmoid wall (Figure B) and possible involvement of the uterus, but no distinct mass (Figure C). It also indicated the presence of a 5.5-cm cystic mass of the right adnexa.
diagnosis: During the next 24 hours, the patient's clinical and radiologic picture deteriorated. Flexible sigmoidoscopy failed to reach the obstruction site and the patient underwent an emergency laparotomy for large bowel obstruction. The patient's recovery was uneventful.

context:
patient_presentation: A 64-year-old man presented for screening esophagogastroduodenoscopy without a chief complaint
physical_exam: The results of his physical examination were normal
initial_laboratory_results: The results of his laboratory testing were unremarkable.
imaging_test_with_photo: EGD revealed a 40-mm elastic hard submucosal tumor located in middle body with great curvature (Figure A). Gastroinestinal stromal tumor, malignant lymphoma, and myoma were suspected initially. Endoscopic ultrasonography revealed that the homogenous lesion originated from the second and third layers.
next_imaging: Ultrasonography and computed tomography revealed a normally functioning heart and normal-sized liver and kindneys (no picture).
diagnosis: Finally, we diagnosed primarily localized gastric amyloidosis from these findings.

context:
patient_presentation: An 84-year-old woman presented with epigastric pain and was admitted for biliary pancreatitis.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory results showed a lipase level of 152 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase level of 183 U/L, alanine aminotransferase level of 102 U/L, total bilirubin level of 4.4 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase level of 80 U/L.
imaging_test_with_photo: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography showed a dilated common bile duct with peri-ampullary biliary stenosis (Figure A).
next_imaging: A dilated bile duct wtih an abrupt terminus just above the duodenal wall and no drainage of contrast to duodenum was seen on endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (Figure B, arrow).
third_imaging: Therefore, a biliary sphincterotomy was performed, and thickened biliary mucosa resembling a polyp was seen (Figure C).
diagnosis: Biliary amyloidoma as a cause for pancreatitis

context:
patient_presentation: A 77-year-old man presented with a 2-day history of abdominal fullness and progressively increasing severe epigastric pain associated with nausea and vomiting.
additional_history: The patient had no previous history of symptoms related to the gastrointestinal tract. He did not smoke or drink.
physical_exam: Physical examination revealed moderate epigastric tenderness.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory tests showed the following significant results: white blood cell count, 17,200/μL; aspartate aminotransferase level, 183 U/L; alanine aminotransferase level, 81 U/L; bilirubin level, 3.60 mg/dL; and amylase level, 3686 U/L.
imaging_without_photo: Abdominal computed tomography scan with contrast material showed a well-defined mass in the second portion of the duodenum.
imaging_test_with_photo: The pancreas was enlarged with fluid, and the main pancreatic duct was slightly dilated (Figure A, B).
next_imaging: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed a large tumor originating in the antrum that had prolapsed through the pylorus into the duodenum (Figure C, endoscopic view in gastric antrum; Figure D, endoscopic view in duodenum).

patient_presentation: A 57-year-old woman presented with episodic epigastric pain radiating to her back for the past 2 years, necessitating oral analgesics.
additional_history: For the preceding 3 months, the pain had increased and required multiple hospitalizations. 
physical_exam: On palpation a vague, soft, horizontally placed, cystic, 10 x 5 cm lump was palpable in the epigastric area.
imaging_test_with_photo: On abdominal roentgenogram multiple calcifications were seen along the pancreatic duct (Figure A), and ultrasonography showed a hugely dilated (4 cm) pancreatic duct (Figure B).
next_imaging: The main pancreatic duct was hugely dilated (4.3 cm) with a suspicious mass in the head of the pancreas (Figures C and D).The dilated pancreatic duct reached up to the anterior abdominal wall (Figure C) and therefore the palpable lump correlated wtih the location of the hugely dilated main pancreatic duct on imaging.
diagnosis: On computed tomography of the abdomen the pancreatic head was irregular, heterogeneous, with coarse calcification, and the tail was atrophic with calcification.

context:
patient_presentation: A 39-year-old Hispanic man with a 7-year history of intermittent left lower quadrant abdominal pain and hematochezia.
additional_history: He is otherwise healthy.
imaging_without_photo: On several computed tomography (CT) scans, there were diffuse colonic diverticula. During acute attacks, inflammatory changes were noted within the pelvis adjacent to a large, inflamed, sigmoid diverticulum. These findings were consistent with acute sigmoid diverticulitis. He was treated with antibiotics. 
imaging_test_with_photo: During colonoscopy, there was significant sigmoid luminal narrowing with near circumferential erythematous and bluish mucosa (Figure A and Video Clip) at 35 cm from the anal verge.
next_imaging: This discolored mucosal segment was actually the base of several elongated and pedunculated polyps (Figure B).
diagnosis: The pedicles of these polyps were hyperemic and adenomatous tissue was not observed. One of these pedunculated polyps was removed through snare polypectomy uneventfully.

context:
patient_presentation: A 53-year-old woman was referred to the Gastroenterology clinic after 5 admissions to the hospital for intractable nausea and vomiting during a period of 8 months.
additional_history: On questioning, the patient describes recurrent episodes of similar symptoms. These begin with the sudden onset of nausea. Often the nausea will be constant for days. During a matter of hours her symptoms will progress to include nonbloody emesis. Often she will vomit 4-6 times a day. Occasionally she will experience nonbloody diarrhea associated with these episodes. She can identify no triggering events or exacerbating factors, although she attributes the recent increase in her symptoms to stress from a family conflict. Warm baths seem to improve her symptoms somewhat. Typically her symptoms are preceded by an aura and migraine headache. Often her headache will resolve before the nausea and vomiting. These episodes have been occurring for about the last 1 1/2 years. She has no history of functional gastrointestinal disorders.
imaging_without_photo: During the course of her multiple hospitalizations the patient was subjected to an extensive evaluation in an attempt to identify an etiology for her symptoms. A magnetic resonance imaging scan of the brain was normal. An abdominal computed tomography scan demonstrated only nonspecific abnormalities. An evaluation of her gallbladder showed a few small gallstones; a hepato-iminodiacetic acid scan was normal. A gastric emptying study performed during an admission for nausea and vomiting showed normal gastric emptying time. A host of disease serologies including amylase and lipase, C1-esterase studies, celaic sprue serologies, human immunodeficiency virus testing, cardiac enzymes, and testing for paraneoplastic syndromes were negative.
diagnosis: No undelying etiology can be found to explain the patient's episodic nausea and vomiting. Initially a positive toxicology for urine cannabinoids prompted consideration of cannabis hyperemesis as a potential etiology....Because of her persistent symptoms and the presence of a few small gallstones on ultrasound, the patient was referred to the surgery clinic for laparoscopic cholecystectomy....She was also referred to a psychiatrist, who evaluated her and diagnosed her with generalized anxiety disorder....The patient's presentation is very suggestive of cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS) because she has recurrent episodes with symptom-free intervals and a history of migraine headache.

context:
patient_presentation: A 50-year-old woman with a 6-month history of moderately severe ulcerative proctitis was hospitalized with bloody diarrhea (>15/day), abdominal pain, and new onset skin and oral lesions.
additional_history: She had a primary non-response to mesalamine and intolerance to oral corticosteroid....She had a mild fever (38.3 C) and other vital signs were stable.
physical_exam: Examination revealed lower abdominal tenderness and tender skin lesions, 0.2-1.5 cm in diameter with a few coalesced vesicles.
initial_laboratory_results: CT tests showed hemoglobin 7 g/dL, albumin 2.5 g/dL, C-reactive protein (CRP) 2.7 mg/dL (normal <0.4 mg/dL), fecal calprotectin (FC) > 1250 μg/g (normal: <50 μg/g); blood cultures and stool test for Clostridioides difficile and other pathogens were negative. 
imaging_without_photo: CT scan with contrast revealed proctitis and sigmoid colitis without evidence of abscess or fistula. Esophagoduodenoscopy was normal.
imaging_test_with_photo: Six weeks prior to hospitalization she developed ulcerations over the buccal mucosa and lips (figure A) followed by eruptions of multiple scattered erythematous lesions over the axillae, trunk and buttocks which eventually evolved into vesicles and pustules, some with central ulceration and crusting (figure B-axilla, C-buttocks).
next_imaging: Colonoscopy showed severely ulcerated mucosa with friability in the rectum (figure D) and sigmoid colon (figure E).

patient_presentation: A 44-year-old woman with spina bifida with resultant colostomy formation for neurogenic bowel in infancy was referred for a mass at her colostomy site.
additional_history: She had no family history of colon cancer. The mass had been increasing in size with tenderness to direct contact, itchiness, and occasional bleeding.
physical_exam: On exam, a 4 cm hard non-mobile mass was appreciated on her stoma.
imaging_test_with_photo: Additionally, small satellite lesions were noted (Figure A, B, C).
diagnosis: Additional studies revealed a carcinoembryonic antigen of 6.7, and abdominal imaging demonstrated only non-specific focal swelling on the stoma.

context:
patient_presentation: A 25-year-old woman of Middle Eastern origin was referred for evaluation of liver disease.
additional_history: She had betathalassemia major and received numerous blood transfusions over 2 decades. She was on Deferasirox....The patient subsequently developed hepatic decompensation, cardiac arrhythmias, and a vertebral fracture, all resulting from excess iron overload in the respective organs.
physical_exam: Physical examination demonstrated hepatosplenomegaly and pitting leg edema.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory testing showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, ferritin of 6566 μg/dL, and elevated liver tests.
imaging_test_with_photo: Figure A shows the signal intensity of the involved organs to be lower (darker) than the paraspinal muscles, indicatve of iron overload.
next_imaging: In Figure D, the dark bone marrow signal in the vertebrae is due to iron overload.
diagnosis: Magnetic resonance imaging showed profound iron overload in several organs, including the liver, pancreas, and spleen.

context:
patient_presentation: A 62-year-old man with a history of adenocarcinoma of the stomach status post subtotal gastrectomy and Billroth II gastrojejunostomy 5 years ago presented with an acute onset of severe epigastric pain associated with bloody emesis.
imaging_test_with_photo: A computed tomography scan of the abdomen suggested a retrograde intussuception of the small-bowel anastomosis into the stomach in addition to pneumatosis of the intussusceptum (Figures A and B).
next_imaging: He underwent upper endoscopy, which showed a large protuberant mass in the stomach with edematous mucosa.
diagnosis: The anastomosis was taken down and a Roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy was performed with partial gastrectomy and partial small-bowel resection. The gastrectomy specimen showed recurrence of an intramucosal adenocarcinoma.

context:
patient_presentation: A 41-year-old woman was referred to our outpatient clinic after routine transabdominal ultrasonography revealing multiple liver nodules, up to 13 mm in diameter, scattered throughout both lobes, with hypoechoic to iseochoic center and hyperechoic peripheral halo, interpreted as suspicious for metastatic disease (Figure A).
additional_history: Her past medical history was unremarkable.
physical_exam: There were no relevant findings on physical examination.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory investigation was only pertinent for mild iron overload (hypoer-ferritinemia, 265.1μg/mL; transferring saturation, 57.5%). HFE gene mutation analysis revealed H63D homozygosity.
imaging_without_photo: Abdominal computed tomography confirmed multiple widespread liver lesions, characterized by a hypodense donut-shaped appearance with a normodense center. No further pathologic findings were seen....Subsequent magnetic resonance imaging confirmed the presence of multiple nodular, well-delineated lesions throughout the liver.
imaging_test_with_photo: ...routine transabdominal ultrasonography revealing multiple liver nodules, up to 13 mm in diameter, scattered throughout both lobes, with hypoechoic to iseochoic center and hyperechoic peripheral halo, interpreted as suspicious for metastatic disease (Figure A).
next_imaging: On T2-weighted sequences these lesions appeared hyperintense to the surrounding liver parenchyma (Figure B), whereas no lesions could be seen on fat-suppressed T2-weighted images (Figure C). Furthermore, no signs of focal lesions on fat-suppressed T1-weighted sequence were found, after intravenous gadolinium-DTPA administration.
diagnosis: Suspecting malignant disease, she had already been submitted to a thorough diagnostic workup with chest x-ray, gastroscopy, colonoscopy, and gyneocologic examination that were unrevealing; tumor markers were within normal range.

context:
patient_presentation: A 29-year-old man presented to a local hospital with sudden onset of right upper quadrant pain and abdominal fullness.
additional_history: He denied history of viral hepatitis or alcoholism. Bedside abdominal sonogram disclosed multiple liver tumors with ascites....Because of suspicious tumor rupture, he was transferred to our hospital.
physical_exam: In he emergency service, rebounding tenderness over whole abdomen was noted. Paracentesis confirmed the presence of bloody ascites (white blood/red blood count, 3620/2,840,000/mm^3).
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory test showed the following: leukocyte count, 11,400/mm^3, hemoglobin, 12.8 g/dL; alanine aminotransferase, 31 U/L; aspartate aminotransferase, 66 U/L; total bilirubin, 2.82 mg/dL; albumin, 3.3 g/dL; and γ-glutamyl-transferase, 142 U/L.
imaging_test_with_photo: Subsequent contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) revealed multiple hypodense hepatic tumors with high-density ascites (Figure A).
next_imaging: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) disclosed diffuse variable sized tumors with low intensity on T1-weighted image and high intensity on T2-weighted image (Figure B and C).
diagnosis: Because of unstable vital signs, the patient underwent emergent transarterial embolization. Serum hepatitis B surface antigen and anti-hepatitis C virus antibody were both undetectable. Tumor markers including α-fetoprotein and carcinoembryonic antigen were normal.

context:
patient_presentation: A 48-year-old woman presented with intractable abdominal pain and nausea for 1 day.
additional_history: She has chronic constipation, having 1 bowel movement per month. 
imaging_test_with_photo: Computed tomography abdomen revealed polysplenia with 5 splenules present on the right side of the abdomen, hepatomegaly, and situs ambiguous (Figures A and B). Further evaluation included echocardiogram, which was negative for any structural abnormalities, and ejection fraction of 55%-60%.
next_imaging: The upper gastrointestinal series showed malrotation (Figure C). These findings are consistent with heterotaxy syndrome with left isomerism. Heterotaxy syndrome is a rare entity that entails disorganized internal organs in the chest and abdomen. Heterotaxy syndrome, unlike pure situs inversus, may cause serious health problems because it is assoiated with structural heart problems and bilaterally bilobed lungs with a long bronchus. In the abdomen, complete asplenia or polysplenia may be seen.
diagnosis: Our patient represents a rare case with functional polysplenules.

context:
patient_presentation: A 72-year-old man presented to the emergency department with epigastric pain and melena.
physical_exam: Oh physical examination, he had mild epigastric tenderness and tarry black stool per rectum....
imaging_test_with_photo: On gastroscopy, a solid, ulcerated, lobulated protruding antral mass of 3.5 cm was observed (Figure A)
next_imaging: A positron emission tomography/computed tomography scan showed diffuse uptake corresponding with the antral finding (Figure C) with no pathologic uptake indicative of disease elsewhere.
diagnosis: Epigastric pain and melena induced by primary gastic melanoma

context:
patient_presentation: A 45-year-old man originally from Peru was referred for endoscopic evaluation for ongoing symptoms of generalized abdominal pain and bloating.
additional_history: His symptoms had been present for more than 20 years but had worsened recently. His last travel to Peru was 4 years ago.
initial_laboratory_results: Stool examination for ova and parasite were negative. Stool cultures for Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, Escherichia coli 0157, and Yersinia infections also were negative. 
imaging_without_photo: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed normal-appearing stomach and duodenum.
imaging_test_with_photo: On colonoscopy examination, colon mucosa appeared normal and superficial ulcerations were noted in the terminal ileum (Figure A).
diagnosis: Histology from ileal ulcers showed focal inflammation and the transverse colon had acute inflammation with eosinophilic infiltration.

context:
patient_presentation: A 67 year old gentleman with history of osteoarthritis on naproxen presented with chronic epigastric abdominal pain.
additional_history: Upper endoscopy 3 years before presentation for abdominal pain showed clean-based, benign antral gastric ulcer with multiple clean-based duodenal ulcers. H. Pylori testing was negative on biopsies. At that time, he was advised to stop using naproxen, and start pantoprazole daily.
imaging_test_with_photo: A computerized tomography obtained at the time of this presentation showed a thickening in the gastric antrum questionable for ulcerative versus mass lesion. A gastroduodenal fistula in the gastric antrum with ulcerated margins, communicating with the duodenal bulb (a), separated by a tissue bridge (b), was found on endoscopy.
next_imaging: Repeat EGD in 3 months showed complete healing of the gastric antral ulcer, with fully canalization of the gastroduodenal fistula (c), and improvement in symptoms.
diagnosis: A gastroduodenal fistula in the gastric antrum with ulcerated margins...was found on endoscopy.

context:
patient_presentation: A 77-year-old Caucasian man with a remote history of renal cell carcinoma status post nephrectomy 20 years ago underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy for persistent dyspepsia.
imaging_test_with_photo: The esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed a 10-mm friable pedunculated polyp in the gastric body (Figure A).
diagnosis: ...consistent with metastatic renal cell carcinoma of the stomach.

context:
patient_presentation: A 48-year-old woman with no past medical history presented to the primary care clinic with right-sided abdominal pain, fatigue, and a 20-pound weight loss over 3 months.
additional_history: She described a short period of heavy alcohol use (a bottle of wine per day for 3 years), although she had been abstinent for 1 year prior to presentation. She has two daughters with Alagille's syndrome. She had no other risk factors for liver disease.
initial_laboratory_results: Initial evaluation revealed abnormal liver biochemical tests (alanine aminotransferase: 130 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase: 107 U/L, alkaline phosphatase: 622 U/L, total bilirubin: 0.9mg/dL). 
imaging_test_with_photo: An abdominal MRI was performed, which revealed multiple well defined focal lesions throughout the liver (Panel A).
next_imaging: A liver biopsy was persued to secure the diagnosis. Remarkably, the 17-gauge needle used for the biopsy bent upon contact with the liver because of the extensive tumor burden (Panel B).
diagnosis: ...moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) consistent wtih the fibrolamellar/oncocytic variant.

context:
patient_presentation: A 60-year-old man was referred to our hospital for a small bowel lesion detected on transabdominal ultrasonography.
additional_history: Endoscopic ultrasonography using mini-probe revealed hypoechoic with hyperechoic mass located mainly in the second to third layer of the jejunal wall.
imaging_test_with_photo: Contrast enhanced computed tomography showed well-demarcated and highly enhanced mass lesion in the small bowel (A).
next_imaging: Ante-grade double-balloon enteroscopy revealed a yellowish submucosal tumor measuring 30 mm in size, located in the jejunum (B).
diagnosis: Ectopic pancreas

context:
patient_presentation: A 57-year-old woman had an incidentally detected pancreatic mass and multiple liver lesions diagnosed on her annual checkup.
additional_history: She was previously healthy and denied any surgery. 
initial_laboratory_results: At presentation, the laboratory findings and tumor markers were within the normal range.
imaging_test_with_photo: The abdominal ultrasound demonstrated an 8.0 x 6.6-cm, heterogeneous mass in the pancreatic tail (Figure A, arrow), and 2 liver masses measuring 5.5 cm (Figure B, arrows).
next_imaging: A computed tomography (CT) scan was subsequently requested. The CT scan showed a large, solid, cystic mass in the tail of the pancreas, with central tiny foci of calcification on the precontrast phase (Figure C, arrows).
third_imaging: Contrast-enhanced CT demonstrated the liver lesions with peripheral hyperenhancement and hypovascular center (Figures D–F, arrows). The pancreatic mass presented peripheral and septal progressive enhancement (Figure E, F, arrowheads), and was associated with occlusion of the splenic vein (Figure E, dashed arrow), and consequent gastric varices (Figures D, E, asterisks).

patient_presentation: A 42-year-old woman presented with dull aching right upper quadrant pain for 3 days.
additional_history: She had associated nonbilious vomiting.
physical_exam: On examination, there was tenderness in the right upper quadrant of abdomen.
initial_laboratory_results: Her laboratory parameters were normal.  
imaging_without_photo: Ultrasonography was reported as showing thickened gallbladder wall with fusiform dilatation of common bile duct and mild dilatation of intrahepatic biliary radicles consistent with a choledochal cyst.
imaging_test_with_photo: Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatiography and contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging, however, showed fusiform dilatation of main portal vein (measuring 26 x 14 mm) at the level of splenoportal confluence (Figure A and B, arrows). Gallbladder was normal. However, there was no evidence of chronic liver parenchymal disease.
next_imaging: Doppler study confirmed the diagnosis of portal vein aneurysm (Figure C and D, arrows).
diagnosis: Doppler study confirmed the diagnosis of portal vein aneurysm.

context:
patient_presentation: A 65-year-old woman with a recent history of jaundice (1 month) complained of right epigastric pain and pruritus. 
additional_history: Her medical history was remarkable for breast adenocarcinoma treated with surgery and irradiation 20 years earlier.
initial_laboratory_results: Preliminary laboratory analyses revealed abnormal liver functions consistent with obstructive jaundice.
imaging_without_photo: Abdominal ultrasound and computed tomography scan showed dilatation of common and intrahepatic bile ducts without lithiasis. Upper digestive endoscopy was normal. Subsequent endoscopic ultrasound revealed normal pancreas and papilla of Vater, and demonstrated stenosis of the common bile duct with major dilatation in the biliary tree. There was no typical feature of choledochal cyst.
imaging_test_with_photo: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) disclosed a stricture (Figure A, arrows) of the hilar biliary duct with marked proximal biliary dilatation. A double biliary endoprothesis was inserted, and sphincterectomy was performed. The cytologic biliary brushing showed no abnormal cells.
next_imaging: CT performed in our institution after portal embolization (small hepatic left lobe) was retrospectively reviewed (Figure B) and small, cystic, nonopacifying lesion (arrow) adjacent to the main biliary duct was observed (long arrow; biliary endoprothesis).
diagnosis: The patient referred to our hospital with the presumed diagnosis of cholangiocarcinoma of the hilum. The patient underwent an extended right hepatectomy with biliary reconstruction by hepaticojejunostomy. Her postoperative recovery was uneventful. Microscopic examination of the hilum and intrahepatic ducts demonstrated severe fibrosis, without adenocarcinoma.

context:
patient_presentation: An 85-year-old woman presented with a 3-day history of abdominal fullness, nausea, and vomiting. 
additional_history: She had no personal history of abdominal surgery.
physical_exam: Physical examination revealed a distended abdomen with increased bowel sounds and diffuse abdominal pain.
initial_laboratory_results: The results of laboratory studies included a white cell count of 16,200/mm^3, a serum creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL, a sodium level of 121 mmol/L, and lactic acid level of 6.1 mmol/L. 
imaging_test_with_photo: Computed tomography of the abdomen revealed a distended colon and numerous loops of small intestine, pneumobilia (Figure 1A, arrow)...
next_imaging: ...related to an extensive cholecystocolonic fistula of 3.5 cm connecting the gallbladder to the hepatic flexure (Figure 1B, C, arrow)...
third_imaging: ...and a gallstone obstructing the sigmoid colon (Figure 1D, arrow).
diagnosis: These findings established the diagnosis of sigmoid gallstone ileus.

context:
patient_presentation: A 19-year-old man with a 2-month history of lower abdominal pain and a 10-kg weight loss during the past year presented with difficulty in passing stool and blood in his stool for 2 days.
physical_exam: Digital rectal examination revealed a large solid mass in the rectum.
initial_laboratory_results: Except for iron deficiency anemia (hemoglobin, 9.3 g/dL; normal, 13-17 g/dL), laboratory test results were unremarkable.
imaging_test_with_photo: Computed tomography of abdomen and pelvis, with and without contrast medium, showed a nonenhancing mass in the rectum, compatible with fecal impaction (Figure A).
next_imaging: A colonoscopy revealed a large intraluminal polypoid hard mass starting about 5 cm above anal verge and extending upward about 12 cm (Figure B). The rectal lumen was almost obstructed by the mass. Endoscopic ultrasound demonstrated a rectal mass invading the perirectal fat pad and involving 1 perirectal lymph node. A biopsy was taken of the mass.
diagnosis: The best histopathologic interpretation was an anaplastic malignant tumor, possibly undifferentiated/anaplastic leiomyoscaroma.

context:
patient_presentation: A 65-year-old woman presented wtih right upper-quadrant abdominal pain, increased liver enzyme levels, and severe sepsis requiring vasopressor support.
additional_history: Computed tomography showed multiple small hepatic hypodensities and a 5-mm distal common bile duct calculus.
imaging_test_with_photo: Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging and MR cholangiopancreatography were performed to evaluate the liver cysts and showed numerous subcentimeter, well-circumscribed, T1-weighted hypointense and T2-weighted hyperintense nonenhancing lesions (Figure A) throughout the hepatic parenchyma with normal-caliber bile ducts consistent with Von Meyenburg complexes or multiple biliary hamartomas (Figure B).
diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with acute cholangitis and underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with sphincterotomy and stone extraction.

context:
patient_presentation: An 86-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with intestinal occlusion.
additional_history: The patient described hepatic colic for several years, which had intensified in recent weeks, associated with fever.
initial_laboratory_results: Laboratory test results showed inflammatory syndrome, cytolysis and anicteric cholestasis.
imaging_test_with_photo: Abdominal computed tomography was performed, which showed a first duodenal obstruction by voluminous gallstone (Figures A and B, red arrow), associated with pneumobilia (white arrow), related to a large cholecystoduodenal fistula. Fistula appeared to be secondary to chronic cholecystitis (Blue arrow).
next_imaging: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed one large stone of 4 cm, just behind the pylorus, in the duodenal bulb (Figures C and D).
third_imaging: The gallstone could be fragmented and extracted using Dormia basket (Figure E).
diagnosis: A diagnosis of Bouveret's syndrome was established, defined as a gastric outlet obstruction due to gallstones with biliary-enteric fistula.

context:
patient_presentation: A 55-year-old female patient presented to our hospital because of 1-month history of melena.
additional_history: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy, colonoscopy and abdominal computed tomography failed to detect a bleeding lesion.
physical_exam: Physical examination showed no mucocutaneous pigmentation in her lip, fingers and toes.
imaging_test_with_photo: Retrograde double-balloon enteroscopy disclosed a tumor with ulcerative surface in the distal ileum (Figure A).
next_imaging: Moreover, the tumor had a thick stalk (Figure B). We performed a polypectomy for the tumor. The resected tumor was approximately 4 cm in size.
diagnosis: ...confirming a diagnosis of hamartomatous polyp.
